results.notes:
Half a dozen fruiting in woodchip mulch bed on residential property. Largest, most mature cap: 6 cm. with prominent rusty brown pyramidal scales. Margin hairy and inrolled in younger specimens and covered with a rusty brown fibrous partial veil at first. As cap expands in maturity the pointed scales remain but are concentrated in the center. Stipe: 3.5 cm. X 1 cm., narrowing toward base. Whitish at apex when immature and covered with rusty brown scales and hairs below. KOH negative on cap. Spore print pending.

I have indicated a low level of confidence because I have never seen this species before and because I also considered Tricholomopsis formosa for the ID. Hopefully, one of the MO experts can help me out with this one.
results.location_name: West St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes:
Common Name: Deer Mushroom
iNat #: 15796006

Nearby Flora: Blackberry bushes, Grass, Morning Glory vines

Substrate: Mixed Wood Chips and humus

Habit: Few (2) growing together in an area where there is Full Sun for extended periods of the day.

Odor: Cut Potato/very-mild Radish scent

Taste: Very-pleasant Potato-like taste and texture

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

Cap: Plane shape with some waviness/undulations irregularly present along w/a downward turn on the larger specimen…caused by the presence of the other specimen. The surface is smooth w/some cracking in the center and along the margin; striated from the center to the margin; light grey-brown…growing darker towards the center which has an Umbus, ~6” wide. Flesh is white, thick, very firm, and w/o bruising or coloration when cut. Somewhat tacky when wet. Margin is upturned.

Gills: Fragile, thin, pale salmon-pink, free, close, broad, and w/o bruising or coloration when cut. There are short, partial gills randomly placed along the margin.

Stipe: White, slightly bulbous at the base, central attachment. The top is about as thick as the base, with the entire stipe having an elliptical shape when viewed from the top. The stipe is smooth w/very fine and closely spaced, vertically running, wavy ridges/fibrils changing from light-to-medium grey-brown at the stipe base. The stipe is ~6” long and ~.5” – .75” wide for the major axis and ~.25” wide at the minor axis of the elliptical shape. Flesh is white, thick, very firm and w/o bruising or coloration when cut.

Spores: Pinkish brown

Mycelia: White, very dense, completely permeating the substrate down to ~ .75”

results.notes: Several scattered within the root zone of an Ash tree in a residential lawn. Cap: 9 cm. Stipe 3 cm. X 2.5 cm. Pores 4 mm. deep. 1 angular pore/mm. Pore surface bruises brown slowly, then turns blackish. Flesh bruises blue when sliced. KOH reddish on cap, pores flash blue then gray, flesh flashes blue then fades. NH4OH orange on cap, blue-black to orange on pores. Olive brown spore print.

results.notes: A trio in grass under Oak on residential property. Specimens appear more gray with a hint of green than is apparent in the posted images. No matter what light the specimens were photographed in, they seemed to look bluer than in actuality. Largest cap: 7 cm., wrinkled and “veined”, gills initially creamy then yellowish, some forked, only at apex of stipe. Stipe: 5 cm. X 1.3 cm., enlarged base, cavernous, lightly streaked with yellow near apex and at the base. KOH yellow on cap. White spore print.

results.notes:
Two fruiting bodies growing in short grass/moss under old oaks.
These look sufficiently different from the typical oak-associated “subvelutipes group” chameleon I’ve collected in the northeast in terms of the cap color, distribution and quality of red pigment in the stipe and the presence of prominent reticulation, but I’ve been fooled before.
I couldn’t get good pictures as it started raining. I noticed that the bluing of the outer surfaces was really enhanced by the moisture.
The larger sporocarp had the following dimensions: cap = 8 cm wide and 2.5 cm thick above the stipe; tubes = 1 cm deep; stipe = 6 cm long, 2 cm wide at the apex and 1.5 cm wide at its narrowest point (~4 cm below apex).
This collection has been preserved, and is scheduled for sequencing.
DNA Results and Discussion:
> Originally, nrLSU was requested for this collection, but PCR failed and instead gave Malassezia sp., which is indicative of insufficient DNA for even nested PCR to give non-random results.
> However, a very short ITS2 fragment (the last 69 bps of the locus) was obtained from a reverse read before the sequence became non-specific/heterogeneous: CYTTAGCTACTAGTCGGTCATAGCGCCGACGAACGTTTGGGGTGGGCCAGGCTGGGTCTGTTTCGAAAC
This fragment perfectly matches the corresponding region in obs 249632.

results.notes:
Several fruiting bodies of approximately the same age (mature to post-mature) growing in moss under old oaks. This entity reminds me of both H. subglabripes and L. rubropunctum, but neither is a 100% gestalt fit. The stipes are straight and short relative to cap widths. The tubes eventually turned deep green upon overnight storage in the fridge. This collection has been preserved, and is scheduled for sequencing. The dried material has a pleasant fungal odor.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 28-Mar-19):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 1565 bps was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma and uploaded to this post. It consists of the last 20 bps of nrSSU, followed by the full-length nrITS (ITS1 = 176 bps, 5.8S = 161 bps, and ITS2 = 220 bps, for a total of 557 bps), and then by the first 988 bps of nrLSU. There are no ambiguous characters in the entire amplicon; it’s a single haplotype.
> BLASTn searches of the nrITS and nrLSU sequences match it perfectly to the corresponding sequences of Logan W’s obs 248795 from Louisiana. For a discussion of the sequencing results see Logan’s post and comments therein.
> Morphologically, this species best fits Hemileccinum, but the ribosomal genes don’t really support this placement. A follow-up with one of the single-copy protein-coding genes has been requested.

A single specimen growing in grass under a mature red oak; other oaks in the vicinity.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 20-Jul-22):
> This collection was sampled for ITS upon my request by Dr. Kudzma.
> Apparently, the reverse read failed and the final ITS sequence was derived from two forward reads (ITS1F and ITS3). This was necessary because the standard forward read originating from the ITS1F primer was not enough to capture the extra-long spacer in its entirety (as it turned out later, the ITS locus in this species is a whopping 1440 base pair long, rivaling in length some of longest Leccinum sequences!!!).
However, even with the two forward reads providing full coverage of the locus, the final ITS sequence is still missing the first 39 bps of the ITS1 region (due to interference from a tall noise stemming from the PCR purification methodology) and the last 240 characters of the ITS2 region. Regarding the short ITS2 sequence, while the ITS3 read goes all the way to LSU, it suffers from 3 separate points of heterogeneity in the ITS2 region (in all cases a 1-base frame shift in one of two haplotypes). Resolution of the haplotypes was stopped shortly after the 2 nd frame shift. The derived partial ITS sequence is 1159 long.
> Dr. Kudzma kindly shared with me the full-length ITS sequence of this beautiful species obtained from his own collection also made in NJ (see the attached photos).
> There are no ITS sequences of this taxon in GenBank. The most similar hits – associated with a species from China – are only 92-93% similar (75% query cover at full-length). Since the ITS sequences of almost all other published Phylloporus spp. are significantly shorter (>1000 bps), problems with sequence alignments will not lead to reliable phylogenetic inferences. Still, at this point in time it appears that the closest relatives of this Gilled Bolete are endemic to Asia.

results.notes: Several tiny specimens fruiting in soil, mixed hardwoods forest, mostly oak and hickory. Representative cap: 2.2 cm., prominently textured umbo. Stipe: 3.5 cm. X 2.5 mm., persistent ring, knob at base with white mycelium. After several hours the stipe and cap margin began to turn a blue-green. results.notes: In lawn below spruce tree. Pores & stem readily bruise blue. Ammonia on cap surface has no effect; on cap flesh bleaches “blue” flesh back to pale tan/beige. This mushroom looks con-specific with a few collections identified as Boletus luridus on this site but seems to differ from most of the pictured collections and from aspects of the description on Wikipedia. The pores are not red and seem wider than typical B. luridus. The stem is short relative to cap diameter; the cap is shades of ocher grading into burnt purples and browns. (Is this more typical of the eastern North American forms?)

results.notes:
Isidiomorphs: present, common, pale-tipped
Bases: distinct, very dark brown to blackened, small degree of cracking
Branching: not constricted and without irregular shape divisions or segmentations; simple dichotomous with many small side branches
Soredia: abundant, especially on terminal branches, probably conglomerating there. Same diameter or almost the same as the width of these branches, but smaller than the width of primary branches, appeared excavate in a few spots.
Fibrils: present, dispersed
Habitat: Fog-rich open slope, at edges of old-growth chaparral, live oak woods and mixed Douglas-fir/hardwood forest
Habit: as photographed, forming dense colonies, but never becoming large or pendulous/subpendulous

results.notes:
It is commonly refered that Lecanographa grumulosa can parasite Dirina massiliensis f. sorediata (see e.g. http://www.lichensmaritimes.org/...). The existence of so many specimens of Dirina massiliensis f. sorediata, covering vast zones of the wall of church refered observation 329486 makes plausible the existence of Lecanographa grumulosa, species that I have found in a neighbour location before (observation 275927 & observation 318173). The specimens from here are entirely similar to those collected before.
Unfortunately my microscope is down and I cannot confirm the micro caracters.

I am not sure of this ID as it is another northern bolete that I stumbled on and have never seen before. I compared it to Boletus spadiceus var. gracilis (as it was suggested to me) but that has apparently been deprecated to Boletus ferrugineus.

Redish cap. Pores dingy yellow and not staining when bruised. Stipe nearly equal or tapered slightly narrower downward. Coarsely reticulate. Basal mycelium whiteish. results.notes:
-2 specimens fruiting in vegetable garden in wood chips
-Large specimen: cap 14 cm x 2.5 cm (including gills), context up to .5 cm thick, thickest near center; stipe 12 cm x 1 – 2.5 cm
-Small specimen: cap 11 cm x 2 cm (including gills), stipe 9 cm x 1 -2 cm
-Caps white, small concentric brown scales, solid brown in center, broad umbo; surface dry, smooth, margins slightly striate and sometimes large v-shaped splits on margins
-context and gills white
-Stem brown, white near apex. Enlarged (bulbous) toward base, then narrowing to a point at bottom with copious white rhizomorphs extending from base
-gills broad, (barely) free, white
-Cap, context, gills, stem bruises yellow, then slowly to dull reddish brown
-Mild taste, no odor detected
-spore print white

results.notes:
This specimen couldn’t help but catch my eye after the first mile or so on my hike towards Mount Marcy in the Adirondacks. I may or may not have encountered this one before. I attempted running it through a Hygrocybe key and the black staining seems to narrow it down considerably. The length of the stipe seems fairly noteworthy, although I am not sure if this rules out H. conica. The stipe length led me towards H. singeri, however, the dark gills don’t seem to be a fit there. I appreciate any help narrowing it down.

Unfortunately, I don’t recall much of the texture of the stipe, despite holding the specimen in the pictures. It did not seem overtly slimy.

results.notes:
Habitat: hardwood log.
Cap: sessile, glabrous, no hairs visible anywhere, flexible and tough, shaped like shoehorns, significantly necking down to point of attachment. New caps sprout, almost as flat-headed periscope projections, from the proximal upper surfaces of existing caps
Pores: 5-6/mm, angular, some patches lacerate
Tubes: 1 mm long
Context: white, 0.5 mm thick, no dark line even at the point of attachment

And: the spores are significantly shorter than the range reported in G & R, but the macroscopic characters fit their description of T. membranacea very well. G & R were aware of specimens from Missouri and Georgia. Spore sizes of Trametes versicolor are a worse fit, not to mention the lack of surface hair and colored zonation. Microporellus obovatus is considerably thicker and usually stalked.

Biotopes: grows in sandy soil, grassy environment, at the foot of oak (Quercus);
Pileus 14-34 mm Ø, hemispherical young, becoming conical-campanulate to campanulate; fibrillous, appressed, brownish beige, with center ± whitish;
Gills adenate to adnexate, crowded, broad, with lamellae and lamellules, obtuse anterior, wedge-like thickness, smooth and concolourous ridge at the gills, beige at first, becoming ordinary gray, browning with age;
Stipe 24-35 × 4-8 mm Ø, cylindrical, equal to ± radicant at base, full, with slight reddish glints from mid to apex, whitish to base, bulbous margined;
Cortine whitish and fugitive
Exhalation spermatic to slightly fungal;
Flavor spermatic;
Spore print brown to cinnamon brown
Macrochemical reaction:
P.D.A.B. = lack of reaction on the flesh of the stipe and the gills;
KOH 10% = lack of reaction on the flesh of the stipe and the gills;
Remarks: It is possible that the MF59601 and MF59602 collection is identical, but I have a slight doubt; then in doubt, I do not abstain.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection. At least two collections picked by the foray participants in mixed woods of hemlock, white pine, birch, oak, maple, and other hardwoods.
While taking the uploaded images, I didn’t notice a single fruiting body of T. felleus hiding among the Retiboletus sporocarps — see the captions under the pix.
This collection reminds me of the conifer-associated taxon I’ve been finding for years in the NJ Pine Barrens [e.g., obs 74396, obs 174953 (long spores), obs 255496, obs 286423, and obs 289404] that somewhat resembles the hardwood-loving R. griseus (e.g., obs 329049), and has been dubbed “R. fuscus sensu Kuo” on MO. M. Kuo describes it on his website: https://www.mushroomexpert.com/retiboletus_fuscus.html. The marco-morphological differences between the two taxa can be readily appreciated.
The exposed stipe flesh of this collection was chrome yellow mixed in with dark burgundy-red areas. The flesh of the caps and upper stipes didn’t stain at all or turned light pinkish-brown.

results.notes: Late season primordia began visibly fruiting 8/1/18 due to record temps(90’s) that persisted beyond average seasonal levels(my estimation). Today, on 8/25/18, they are intermediate in age with thick leading “marshmallowy” growth edge thicker than the varnished context with the expected yellow and bright red zones typical for this stage. At full maturity(usually 3 weeks later if temps are 80F or above) they will be uniform in thickness, varnished burgundy throughout(for the most part) and covered with spore dispersal atop the entire fruiting body(electrostatic activity common with all Ganoderma and other polypores during full reproduction. I also hypothesize that the recent poor air quality(heavy smoke from BC fires at levels nearing 200) and CO2 levels could be contributing to a more rapid and prolific fruiting season this summer for G. oregonense and other annual polypores. Will continue to monitor this canopy until cold sets in and fruiting bodies cease rapid growth for the year(usually late September).
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Late season primordia began visibly fruiting 8/1/18 due to record temps(90’s) that persisted beyond average seasonal levels(my estimation). Today, on 8/25/18, they are intermediate in age with thick leading “marshmallowy” growth edge thicker than the varnished context with the expected yellow and bright red zones typical for this stage. At full maturity(usually 3 weeks later if temps are 80F or above) they will be uniform in thickness, varnished burgundy throughout(for the most part) and covered with spore dispersal atop the entire fruiting body(electrostatic activity common with all Ganoderma and other polypores during full reproduction. I also hypothesize that the recent poor air quality(heavy smoke from BC fires at levels nearing 200) and CO2 levels could be contributing to a more rapid and prolific fruiting season this summer for G. oregonense and other annual polypores. Will continue to monitor this canopy until cold sets in and fruiting bodies cease rapid growth for the year(usually late September).

UPDATE ON 9/11/18: Returned to photograph and harvest at full maturity but found that someone had already harvested it by slicing at the stem base. Re-fruiting has already begun and vibrant white primordial growth is covering the cut wound area. I occasionally use this method, as well. However, I now find it more beneficial for furthering the species to harvest the entire fruiting body(stem and all) from the substrate and use the harvested stem butts to inoculate new Western Hemlock host logs/trees to insure longer range propagation of the species. Whoever continues to harvest my monitoring spots in this location year after year has actually helped to make an interesting revelation and topic of conversation regarding propagation and harvesting. Either way, whether slicing for re-fruiting or completely uprooting and transplanting/inoculating other host trees with the harvested stem butts, the host tree is already fully infected with the living mycelium of the organism and will continue to fruit in the location until all desired food(lignin) has been depleted. I think using the re-fruit method with younger collections is wise, while full harvest and stem butt transplant is best for nearly or fully mature sporophores(for not only Reishi but other saprophytic and parasitic species). With ecto-mycorrhizal species this topic is of no concern and the always used metaphor of a “apple from a tree” does not effect the mycelium and propagation hypogeously of the organism. However, as with truffle hunters, it can be a very detrimental practice to tear up soil networks continually in an area and will eventually erase the species from a forest if annually harvested year after year without reintroducing new trees and inoculations every few seasons(e.g. commercial Matsutake hunters in National forests). With saprophytes such as Ganoderma we can trust that they will always find a way to eat and propagate, regardless of our interference, and often times, because of it.
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes: Late season primordia began visibly fruiting 8/1/18 due to record temps(90’s) that persisted beyond average seasonal levels(my estimation). Today, on 8/25/18, they are intermediate in age with thick leading “marshmallowy” growth edge thicker than the varnished context with the expected yellow and bright red zones typical for this stage. At full maturity(usually 3 weeks later if temps are 80F or above) they will be uniform in thickness, varnished burgundy throughout(for the most part) and covered with spore dispersal atop the entire fruiting body(electrostatic activity common with all Ganoderma and other polypores during full reproduction. I also hypothesize that the recent poor air quality(heavy smoke from BC fires at levels nearing 200) and CO2 levels could be contributing to a more rapid and prolific fruiting season this summer for G. oregonense and other annual polypores. Will continue to monitor this canopy until cold sets in and fruiting bodies cease rapid growth for the year(usually late September). I harvested this specimen a bit early(although spore dispersal has already begun to ensure wanted Western Hemlock infections to come) to show intermediate interior of the species and the progression of uniformity between the spore tubes and pith interior(see image#4 to compare with many of my other harvest posts in the database for G. oregonense).

notes_fields.Habitat: Mulched ground in urban setting underneath of shrubs
notes_fields.Taste_and_Odor: Phenolic (unpleasant) or slightly sweet or slightly “spermatic” (maybe just where KOH was applied)
notes_fields.Chemical_Reactions: 5% KOH yellow on surface and context of stipe and cap, turning brown-orange over time
notes_fields.Macroscopic_Features:
Larger mature mushroom – Pileus 14 cm diameter. Stem 13.5 cm long and 1.5 cm wide with a 2.0-2.5 cm wide basal bulb and persistent ring that is thick and rubbery looking like a gasket.

Smaller mature mushroom – Pileus 7.5 cm diameter. Stem hollow, 12 cm long and 1 cm wide with an abrupt basal bulb 1.5 cm wide. White rhizomorphs extend from the base.

Stem bruises brownish yellow. When cut, the stem context and especially the basal bulb turn yellow, but darken over time to brown orange, as well as the context of the cape above the attachment point of the stipe. KOH is positive on all surfaces turning bright yellow then darkening to brown orange.
notes_fields.Microscopic_Features: Spores ellipsoid, length (4.8) 5.2-6.0 (6.3) x width (3.2) 3.4-3.9 (4.0), Q (1.3) 1.5-1.6 (1.7), 21 spores measured.
